Label: Annoyed
Comment: I felt pretty annoyed watching the overbearing mother repeatedly interrupt and answer questions on behalf of her capable adult son.

Label: Beside Myself
Comment: I felt beside myself with anger when an elderly person was admitted due to severe neglect in their nursing home.

Label: Blood Boiled
Comment: My blood was boiling when I learned the child had permanently loss the use of their legs due to a drunk driver.

Label: Enraged
Comment: During the consult scene, I became enraged seeing the parents refusing to refer to their child as his chosen gender identification.

Label: Frustrated
Comment: Seeing the friend lie about drug use and hinder the nurses' ability to treat the patient was really frustrating.

Label: Fuming
Comment: I was fuming watching the dad yell at his underage daughter for drinking while she was getting her stomach pumped.

Label: Furious
Comment: It made me furious to see the doctor focus solely on one possible diagnosis, which meant she missed crucial symptoms of a different issue.

Label: Incensed
Comment: Incensed is the only way to describe how I felt when the patient was told her misdiagnosis had allowed her condition to go beyond treatable.

Label: Infuriated
Comment: Watching the drug-seeking patient lie about his symptoms to obtain painkillers was incredibly infuriating.

Label: Irked
Comment: I understood why, but it irked me to see the nurses refuse the panicked off-duty nurse entry when her father was brought in.

Label: Irritated
Comment: It was irritating to watch the elderly man refuse care from any nurses except the young females.

Label: Livid
Comment: I felt livid seeing the poor babies experiencing withdrawal due to their mothers ingesting drugs while pregnant.

Label: Maddening
Comment: The police who insisted they needed to question the patient, despite the doctors saying the patient was in no condition to do so, were maddening.

Label: Outraged
Comment: I felt outraged when the police would not allow the parents to see their child who had been shot until they were finished questioning him.

Label: Seething
Comment: Hearing the parent baffled to discover her smoking had triggered the child's asthma and landed her in emergency had me seething.

Label: Up the Wall
Comment: It drove me up the wall to watch the girlfriend yell at the nurse when they refused to let her see her boyfriend due to protocol.

Label: Appalled
Comment: I was appalled by how the conservative mother reacted when her daughter admitted to the doctor she might be pregnant.

Label: Bilious
Comment: I felt bilious as the doctor administered a needle into a laceration, explaining this avoids the intact nerves of the surrounding skin.

Label: Ghastly
Comment: I felt ghastly when the patient with circulation issues had a dressing change and the tip of the blackened toe came loose.

Label: Grossed Out
Comment: The sight of the tick head that had become embedded within a patient's chest really grossed me out.

Label: Hideous
Comment: Learning about necrotizing fasciitis, a flesh eating bacteria that can form in infected skin, made me feel hideous.

Label: Nauseated
Comment: I felt nauseated by the visuals of the man who came in to have a fishing lure removed from his leg.

Label: Queasy
Comment: During the operation scene, the visuals of the patient's stomach made me feel incredibly queasy.

Label: Repelled
Comment: The imagery of the long-term coma patient who had developed large bed sores was repelling.

Label: Repugnant
Comment: The scene where the nurse had to remove maggots from the patients infected leg wound was repugnant.

Label: Repulsed
Comment: I felt repulsed watching the nurse change the bandages of the patient with a gangrene infected foot.

Label: Revolted
Comment: It was revolting to watch the intoxicated patient projectile vomit all over the nurse trying to take her blood pressure.

Label: Sickened
Comment: During an emergency room scene, imagery of the man whose leg had gone through a wood chipper was incredibly sickening.

Label: Skin Crawl
Comment: When the football player came into emergency, the gruesome imagery of the exposed bone made my skin crawl.

Label: Stomach-Turned
Comment: My stomach turned at the sight of the patient with third-degree burns having their bandages changed.

Label: Uncomfortable
Comment: When the man came in after a bar fight, the sight of his bloody and dislocated jaw made me uncomfortable.

Label: Vile
Comment: When they wheeled in the child in anaphylactic shock, the sight of all the hives covering their chest was vile.

Label: Afraid
Comment: I was really afraid to learn the outcome of the separation surgery, where they attempted to separate conjoined infants.

Label: Alarmed
Comment: Seeing that even a healthy woman in her mid-thirties could suffer from a heart attack really alarmed me.

Label: Anxious
Comment: It was pretty anxiety-provoking hearing the doctor explain a heart attack and how the muscles and organs consequently stop functioning.

Label: Apprehensive
Comment: I felt apprehensive while the doctor listed the internal bleeding signs the car accident victim was showing.

Label: Frightened
Comment: Watching the nurses attempt to restrain the violent, thrashing patient was positively frightening.

Label: Nerve-racking
Comment: The moments before the burn victim's reconstructed face was revealed were extremely nerve-racking.

Label: Nervous
Comment: I felt really nervous for the elderly patient undergoing a surgery that would be very taxing on their weak heart.

Label: On Edge
Comment: The scene in which the patient reacted to the medication and had a seizure had me on edge throughout.

Label: Petrified
Comment: While a patient was bleeding out from a hunting accident, I was petrified that it took so long for them to notice the second gunshot wound.

Label: Scared
Comment: It was pretty scary to see the diabetic having to come in monthly for eye injections to prevent vision loss.

Label: Stressed
Comment: It was stressful to hear the confusion in the doctor's voice as a resting patient had a rapidly increasing heart-rate and blood pressure.

Label: Tense
Comment: The waiting room scene, where the family waited to hear the surgery outcome, was incredibly tense.

Label: Terrified
Comment: Watching the doctor cut a hole in the patient's neck to insert a breathing tube, because they were vomiting too much blood, was terrifying.

Label: Traumatised
Comment: It was traumatising to see an accidental high dose of fentanyl cause a patient to go into respiratory failure and almost die.

Label: Uneasy
Comment: It made me pretty uneasy to watch the still drunk patient who had fallen receive stitches in their head.

Label: Worried
Comment: It was worrying watching the patient's swallow test and seeing the fluid drip into her lungs without even making her cough.

Label: Awful
Comment: Watching the doctor coldly report to the family that their son had not survived the surgery made me feel awful.

Label: Demoralised
Comment: It was demoralising to see the father be told he had permanently paralysed his child when he had pulled her from the car wreck.

Label: Depressed
Comment: It was immensely depressing watching the couple receive the news their unborn child had not survived the car crash.

Label: Despaired
Comment: I despaired watching the nurses use the defibrillator over and over to no avail on the patient.

Label: Despondent
Comment: The scene where the mother was forced to choose between her own life and her baby's left me feeling despondent.

Label: Devastated
Comment: I felt devastated for the family who had to make the decision whether to continue life support when the patient was pronounced brain dead.

Label: Discouraged
Comment: It was pretty discouraging when the nurse explained to the patient if she kept pulling out her ventilator she would die and she replied, I know.

Label: Disheartened
Comment: It was disheartening to hear the up-and-coming athlete had an infection which meant the leg needed to be amputated.

Label: Disillusioned
Comment: Seeing the homeless woman who came to emergency with fake complaints just for a place to spend the night was disillusioning.

Label: Down
Comment: It brought me down to hear the elderly patient say they had given up and requested a 'do-not-resuscitate' order.

Label: Heart Bled
Comment: My heart bled for the couple who had been trying for years and received news their pregnancy was ectopic and unlikely to survive.

Label: Heart-Wrenching
Comment: Seeing the dementia patient who could not remember his own family was absolutely heart-wrenching.

Label: Miserable
Comment: It made me miserable when they had to explain to the elderly patient why the move to palliative care would be permanent.

Label: Teared Up
Comment: I teared up when the patient was told their newly transplanted heart was being rejected by their body.

Label: Terrible
Comment: I felt terrible for the family who had to decide whether to put their elderly father through an extremely risky surgery for the chance of survival.

Label: Upset
Comment: It was incredibly upsetting to watch the car crash survivor learn she was the only one of her 4 friends to survive.

Label: Admiration
Comment: I felt deep admiration for terminal cancer patient having surgery just to extend her life for a few months to have more time with her family.

Label: Amazed
Comment: I was amazed by the war veteran receiving stitches who refused anaesthesia and didn't wince a single time.

Label: Astonished
Comment: I felt astonished at the selflessness of the brother who donated his kidney to his older sister.

Label: Empowered
Comment: I felt empowered watching the young boy who had a tumour removed and permanent mobility consequences still so energetic and playful.

Label: Encouraged
Comment: It was encouraging to learn the medical staff brainstorm with each other when they encounter a perplexing symptom presentation.

Label: Excited
Comment: I felt excited on behalf of the intensive care patient who graduated from being intubated to minimal breathing support.

Label: Exhilarating
Comment: Following the cardiac doctor as she prepped herself and the bed after receiving a page about an incoming heart attack patient was exhilarating.

Label: Heartwarming
Comment: Watching the infant receive hearing aids and hear his parents' voices for the first time was incredibly heartwarming.

Label: Impressed
Comment: I felt very impressed with how easily the nurse calmed the screaming child so she could administer the needle.

Label: Inspired
Comment: I felt really inspired by the heart surgeon who chose that career path after losing a parent to heart complications when he was young.

Label: Invigorated
Comment: After hearing the backstory of the girl in the rehabilitation clinic, the scene of her standing unaided for the first time was invigorating.

Label: Marvelled
Comment: I marvelled at the determination and strength of the mother who successfully delivered triplets.

Label: Motivated
Comment: It was really motivating to see the weight loss improvement of a patient how had received a gastric band 6-months prior.

Label: Moved
Comment: It moved me to hear the story of the couple who finally successfully conceived after multiple rounds of in vitro fertilisation.

Label: Respect
Comment: I felt deep respect for the nurses who have to console families after they lose a family member.

Label: Uplifted
Comment: It was uplifting the see the palliative care patient whose daughter would visit everyday after work.

Label: Appreciated
Comment: I really appreciated the man who volunteered his time to visit the children's ward dressed as their favourite superheroes.

Label: Assured
Comment: I felt assured there are nurses that support the lonely patients in palliative care who have often been abandoned by their family.

Label: Blessed
Comment: I felt blessed on behalf of the new parents whose premature baby was finally strong enough to be allowed home.

Label: Calmed
Comment: After the patient underwent a cystectomy due to cancer in the bladder, it calmed me to learn they were expected to make a full recovery.

Label: Comforted
Comment: It was comforting to see, after several months, a match had been found for the patient awaiting a lung transplant.

Label: Consoled
Comment: After losing the mother to childbirth, I was consoled seeing the father hold his healthy newborn child.

Label: Fortunate
Comment: I felt we are fortunate to have such kind and understanding nurses working with those coming in and out of psychosis episodes.

Label: Glad
Comment: I felt really glad on behalf of the kid who finally had his tonsils removed after having tonsillitis several times in the last year.

Label: Gratifying
Comment: As a registered organ donor, it was incredibly gratifying to see a 10 year old given a second chance at life after a heart transplant.

Label: Pleased
Comment: I felt pleased to see how the nurse explained the complex procedure in child-friendly language to the boy.

Label: Reassured
Comment: It reassured me to learn the staff at the hospital have free access to a resident mental health professional.

Label: Relaxed
Comment: It relaxed me to learn all nurses on the ward are made aware of the high risk patients so they are ready to aid the assigned nurse.

Label: Rewarded
Comment: It felt rewarding to see the mother hold her newborn after a complicated birth where the umbilical cord almost strangled the baby.

Label: Satisfied
Comment: Maybe some people wouldn't, but I found it really satisfying when they were draining the patient's cyst.

Label: Soothed
Comment: Given no family or visitors had come for a while, I felt soothed to see a nurse request to sit by an elderly patient's bed while he passed.

Label: Thankful
Comment: I felt thankful for how far plastic surgery has come after seeing the reconstruction of the burn victim's face.

Label: Amused
Comment: Maybe I shouldn't have, but I found the huge swollen lips of the patient with the shellfish allergy really amusing.

Label: Cheered Up
Comment: After some gruesome scenes, it cheered me up to see a nurse weigh a child by weighing himself then standing on the scale holding the child.

Label: Chuckle
Comment: I had a good chuckle at the man trying to reason why he had inserted the object into his rectum.

Label: Chuffed
Comment: I felt chuffed to see a patient, who was unresponsive to medication, have their tremor reduced after the installation of neurostimulator.

Label: Delighted
Comment: The therapy dog doing her rounds in the children's ward was absolutely delightful to watch.

Label: Ecstatic
Comment: I felt ecstatic for the eating disorder patient who, after months, graduated from inpatient to outpatient.

Label: Elated
Comment: I felt elated watching the elderly couple reunited after the husband had successfully had a pacemaker installed.

Label: Giggle
Comment: I had a giggle hearing that nurses use Code Brown, for bowel movements, as a play on Code Blue, for respiratory and cardiac failure.

Label: Good Mood
Comment: It put me in a good mood to hear the comatose patient was showing signs of improved mental activity.

Label: Joy
Comment: I felt joy for the on-call doctors who managed to get through the New Year's count before they were interrupted by their pagers.

Label: Laughed
Comment: It made me laugh when the child came in to get a piece of Lego removed which they had inserted up their nose.

Label: Lifted Spirits
Comment: It really lifted my spirits to see the young girl receive and try out her brand new prosthetic leg.

Label: Optimistic
Comment: I felt optimistic when the doctor said the survival rate for babies with the intestine growing outside the body is 90%.

Label: Over the Moon
Comment: I felt over the moon when they finally found the dementia patient safe and sound after they had gone walkabouts.

Label: Overjoyed
Comment: I felt overjoyed when the doctor announced after months of chemotherapy, the patient was finally cancer free.

Label: Smiled
Comment: I couldn't help smiling seeing the nurses using humour and banter to keep their spirits up during their shifts.

Label: Absorbed
Comment: I was absorbed by how the incubators simulate conditions in the mother's womb for the premature babies.

Label: Captivated
Comment: Learning about rotationplasty, where a rotated ankle is reattached to function as a knee to which a prosthetic is attached, was captivating.

Label: Curious
Comment: I was burning with curiosity when introduced to the man who had acquired savant syndrome as a result of a head injury.

Label: Eager
Comment: I felt eager to learn more about how PET detect cancer using a chemical that is absorbed by cancerous cells.

Label: Enchanted
Comment: I was enchanted watching how engaged and delighted the mental health inpatients were in the music therapy session.

Label: Engaged
Comment: It was incredibly engaging to watching the doctor put together the symptoms like a puzzle to come to diagnosis.

Label: Engrossed
Comment: I felt engrossed by the case of the amputee with phantom limb syndrome, where he was feeling pain in a missing hand.

Label: Enthralled
Comment: During the coronary angiogram, imaging of the heart's blood circulation, I was enthralled seeing blood begin to flow once the blockage was removed.

Label: Enthusiastic
Comment: Hearing the woman likely survived her heart attack due to how active she was made me a bit more enthusiastic about working out.

Label: Entranced
Comment: I was entranced watching the patient awake during brain surgery so they could ensure the functions of the operated on area remained intact.

Label: Fascinated
Comment: I found it fascinating to watch how calmly the surgeons and nurses communicated during the operation.

Label: Gripped
Comment: I felt absolutely gripped when they doctor used adenosine, which stops and restarts the heart, to treat an irregular heartbeat.

Label: Intrigued
Comment: It was incredibly intriguing to hear the doctor explain how the severed finger was still able to be reattached.

Label: Involved
Comment: I became really involved when the husband began describing memories with his wife who was in intensive care for brain swelling.

Label: Riveting
Comment: Watching how fast paced the nurses worked to get the treatment undergoing in the emergency ward was riveting.

Label: Thrilled
Comment: I felt thrilled on behalf of the 10 year old who had been waiting a year for a heart transplant and was finally going to receive one.
